question.title: At the Paris Summer Olympics in 2024, will the men's 100m dash winning time break the Olympic record of 9.63s?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if any athlete runs the Men's 100M race at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics in less than 9.63s, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: The current Olympic record for the men's 100m dash is 9.63 seconds, set by Usain Bolt in the 2012 London Olympics. Since Bolt's retirement, no athlete has consistently approached or surpassed this time in major competitions. The world record remains at Bolt's 9.58 seconds, set in 2009, and breaking the Olympic record would require an unprecedented performance unlikely given the current competitive landscape. Additionally, recent Olympic winning times have been significantly slower than the record, indicating that a sub-9.63s performance is highly improbable.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The current world record for the men's 100m dash is 9.58 seconds, set by Usain Bolt in 2009. Given the historical performance trends and the current capabilities of top sprinters, it is unlikely that the winning time will break 9.70 seconds.

question.title: Between July 17 and July 28, 2024, will the strongest geomagnetic storm have a K-index ("Kp") greater than 4 and less than or equal to 6?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if the highest Planetary K-index ("Kp") between July 17 and July 28, 2024 (inclusive) is greater than 4 and less than or equal to 6, according to the German Research Center for Geosciences in their running 30-day history data product.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Geomagnetic storms are primarily driven by solar activity, including solar flares and coronal mass ejections (CMEs). The K-index measures the magnitude of geomagnetic disturbances on a scale from 0 to 9, with higher values indicating more intense storms. Solar activity follows an approximately 11-year cycle, with periods of higher and lower activity. As of late 2023, we are approaching the peak of Solar Cycle 25, which is expected around 2025. During solar maximum periods, the frequency and intensity of geomagnetic storms generally increase. However, predicting the exact occurrence and strength of specific geomagnetic events several months in advance remains challenging due to the complex and unpredictable nature of solar phenomena. Considering the current phase of the solar cycle and historical data on geomagnetic activity, there is a moderate likelihood of experiencing a geomagnetic storm with a Kp index greater than 4 and less than or equal to 6 between July 17 and July 28, 2024.

question.title: Will Deadpool & Wolverine have biggest opening weekend ever for R-rated movie? [ahead of Deadpool I & II, It, Joker]
question.body:
Analysts are projecting a huge opening weekend for "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover movie.
https://deepnewz.com/movies/deadpool-wolverine-set-record-360m-global-opening-weekend-biggest-r-rated-debut

"""

The film, directed by Shawn Levy and starring Ryan Reynolds, is projected to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally in its opening weekend. This would mark the biggest opening weekend ever for an R-rated movie. Domestically, the film is expected to debut with $160 million to $170 million, making it the biggest R-rated opening of all-time.

"""

[image]The record for biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie is the original Deadpool at $284.5M ($152.2M domestic).

https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movies/movie-news/box-office-deadpool-makes-history-865143/

[image]
Will the new movie top these marks? It will probably be close...

It will certainly play at more theaters... Deadpool was a smash hit at the time, and a bit surprising.

Since BoxOfficeMojo is a bit weird on reporting international opening weekends -- it provides the raw numbers but aggregates them weirdly -- we will wait for Hollywood Reporter to let us know what the weekend opening was.

To clarify on resolution...
-> this market will resolve YES if Deadpool x Wolverine grosses more than $284.5M globally this opening weekend according to reports
-> AND the Hollywood Reporter (or equivalent publication) reports it as the record for an R-rated movie release

In other words the BoxOfficeMojo numbers should be seen as unofficial until there's confirmation in the Hollywood press. And the number we shoot for is >$284.5M internationally... this weekend

metadata.chain_of_thought: The upcoming "Deadpool x Wolverine" crossover leverages the combined fan bases of two highly popular franchises. The original "Deadpool" set the record for the biggest opening weekend for an R-rated movie with $284.5 million globally. Analysts are projecting "Deadpool x Wolverine" to earn between $340 million and $360 million globally, which would surpass the previous record by a significant margin. Factors supporting this projection include the star power of Ryan Reynolds, the expanded theatrical release, and strong marketing efforts. Additionally, the crossover aspect adds novelty and excitement, likely attracting a broader audience. However, projections can sometimes be optimistic, and actual performance may be influenced by competing releases and market conditions at the time of release. Given the strong indicators and historical performance, it is likely that the movie will achieve the projected figures and set a new record for R-rated movies.

2. **Previous Box Office Performance**: "Deadpool" had a strong opening despite being R-rated, indicating robust fan turnout. "The Wolverine" had a moderate opening, suggesting a solid but not overwhelming initial draw.
   
3. **Market Trends**: The superhero genre continues to perform well, but market saturation and competition from other major releases around the same time could impact box office numbers.
   
4. **Marketing and Hype**: Effective marketing campaigns and positive pre-release buzz can significantly boost opening numbers. The collaboration between two popular characters may generate substantial media coverage and anticipation.
   
5. **Release Timing**: The chosen release window can affect performance. If released during a peak movie-going period with minimal competition, the opening could be stronger.
   
6. **Economic Factors**: General economic conditions, such as consumer spending power and discretionary income, play a role in movie-going behavior.

Considering these factors, the synergy of combining two major Marvel characters, strong marketing potential, and favorable market conditions could make surpassing the combined $185.5 million opening plausible. However, potential competition and market saturation pose risks that moderate the likelihood.

question.title: Will diplomatic expulsions or recalls take place between the Philippines and China before August 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if before August 1, 2024, one of these four events happens, according to official statements or [credible reports](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions): 

- The Philippines expels at least one diplomat representing the People's Republic of China (PRC). 

- The Philippines recalls at least one of its diplomats stationed in the PRC.

- The PRC expels at least one diplomat representing the Philippines.

- The PRC recalls at least one of its diplomats stationed in the Philippines. 

If there are no such reports before that date, then this resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the diplomatic relationship between the Philippines and China is characterized by both cooperation and tension. Economically, China is a significant trading partner and investor in the Philippines, fostering mutual dependency that typically discourages drastic diplomatic actions such as expulsions or recalls. However, territorial disputes in the South China Sea have been a persistent source of tension. While these disputes have led to diplomatic strains in the past, both nations have generally preferred to address these issues through negotiations and international legal mechanisms rather than through overt diplomatic hostilities. Additionally, there hasn't been a recent escalation that would strongly indicate an impending decision to expel or recall diplomats. Given the current state of affairs and the potential negative repercussions of such actions on bilateral relations and economic ties, it is unlikely that either the Philippines or China would pursue diplomatic expulsions or recalls before August 1, 2024.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

question.title: Will "Twisters" (2024) have a Rotten Tomatoes critics score of at least 75%? ("Certified Fresh")
question.body:
"Twisters" (2024) Rotten Tomatoes page

This resolves YES if the Tomatometer score is 75% or higher, one week after release (July 26th). 

Details 

I will use whatever precision is listed by Rotten Tomatoes (typically an integer percentage, no decimal).

For example, the original "Twister" (1996) currently has a Tomatometer of 63%. This is the equivalent score I will use.

"Certified Fresh" is just used for illustrative purposes (AFAIK, it requires >=75% Tomatometer, but there might be other restrictions—the market resolves solely based on the displayed score).

"Twisters" (2024) is a standalone sequel to the 1996 original, directed by Lee Isaac Chung ("Minari"), starring Glen Powell ("Top Gun: Maverick") and Daisy Edgar Jones ("Normal People").

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that "Twisters" (2024) will achieve a Rotten Tomatoes Tomatometer score of at least 75%, we can consider several factors:

1. **Director's Track Record**: Lee Isaac Chung gained critical acclaim for "Minari," which received high praise for its storytelling and direction. His involvement suggests a focus on quality and depth, which could positively influence critical reception.

2. **Cast**: Glen Powell and Daisy Edgar Jones are both recognized actors with growing portfolios. Their performances can significantly impact critics' perceptions and overall score.

3. **Original Film's Reception**: The original "Twister" (1996) has a Tomatometer score of 63%. As a standalone sequel, "Twisters" has the opportunity to build upon the original's legacy while introducing new elements, potentially attracting both fans and new audiences.

4. **Genre and Market Trends**: Action-adventure films with strong narratives and character development tend to perform well critically, especially when led by acclaimed directors and talented casts. Current market trends favor well-executed sequels that offer fresh perspectives.

5. **Lack of Pre-release Reviews**: Since the movie hasn't been released yet and assuming no significant controversies or production issues, the anticipation might be cautiously optimistic among critics.

Considering these factors, while there is positive potential due to the director and cast, achieving a 75% or higher score is moderately likely but not guaranteed, especially given the original's moderate score.

question.title: Will Russian athletes be barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Russian athletes are barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics under either (i) the Russian flag, (ii) The Russian Olympic Committee's flag, or (iii) any other independent or neutral flag. This will resolve based on the official list of countries and athletes present at the [2024 Olympics](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/paris-2024) or based on credible media reports, indicating that the 2024 Olympics are underway or have concluded without Russian participation. For the question to resolve as **Yes**, no more than 34 Russians can be competing at the 2024 Olympics. 34 was chosen as 10% of [Russian athletes that participated in the 2020 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Olympic_Committee_athletes_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics) to allow for a few individual or sport specific exceptions.

If more than 34 Russian athletes compete at the 2024 Olympics, this question will resolve as **No**.

If the 2024 Olympics are cancelled or postponed to 2025 or afterwards, this question resolves as ambiguously.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historically, Russian athletes have faced restrictions in the Olympics due to doping scandals, leading to bans or the requirement to compete under neutral flags such as the Russian Olympic Committee (ROC). The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has balanced the need to penalize state-sponsored doping while allowing clean athletes to compete by permitting participation under neutral designations. Unless there is significant new evidence of systemic doping or geopolitical tensions that compel the IOC to implement a full ban, it is likely that Russian athletes will continue to compete in the 2024 Olympics under a neutral flag rather than being entirely barred. Given the IOC's previous approach and lack of indications for a complete prohibition, the probability that Russian athletes will be fully barred is relatively low.

question.title: Will OpenAI publicly commit to the "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle before July 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if, before July 1, 2024, both of the following are true:

- OpenAI publicly commits to the "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle via a statement from the company or a company spokesperson, such as Sam Altman. The statement may be formal (such as a press release) or informal (such as a tweet or quote in an interview). The statement from OpenAI must indicate a new level of commitment to the principle in question, relative to the time the righttowarn.ai statement was published; it cannot be a reiteration that, for example, "we already have a culture of open criticism". 
- Metaculus verifies that the company has accepted the principle to the satisfaction of at least one member of righttowarn.ai. Metaculus may reach out to select signatories or endorsers to assess their level of satisfaction with OpenAI's commitment. Statements must be at least as rigorous as "this was a good first step" for this question to resolve as **Yes**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, OpenAI has consistently emphasized transparency and responsible disclosure regarding the potential risks of its AI technologies. While OpenAI has policies that encourage the reporting of risks and discourage retaliation, there hasn't been a specific public commitment articulated as the "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle in the exact terms described. Given OpenAI's track record of engaging with the broader community and addressing concerns related to AI safety and ethics, it is plausible that they might make such a commitment by July 1, 2024. However, without concrete announcements or evidence to confirm this specific commitment, there remains uncertainty.

question.title: Will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question resolves as **No** if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in these eight team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics: 

- association football 
- 3×3 basketball
- 5×5 basketball
- field hockey
- handball 
- rugby sevens
- volleyball
- water polo.

Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **Yes**.

However, challenges remain, including differing national interests, concerns over sovereignty, and debates on funding mechanisms. The upcoming WHA in May 2024 is expected to benefit from the ongoing dialogue and incremental progress made over the past years. Considering the heightened global awareness of pandemic preparedness and the collaborative efforts observed, it is moderately likely that the Pandemic Agreement will receive the necessary approval during the assembly.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Invoking the 25th Amendment Section 4 to declare President Biden incapacitated would require the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to formally assert his inability to discharge the duties of the office. Historically, such actions have been exceedingly rare and are typically reserved for clear and undeniable instances of incapacity. As of now, there is no substantial evidence or widespread support within the Cabinet or among key political figures to suggest that this process is being seriously considered. Additionally, political motivations alone, without clear indications of incapacity, are unlikely to drive such a significant constitutional action. Given these factors, it is improbable that the 25th Amendment Section 4 will be invoked against President Biden before August 2024.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before September?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before September 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to declare a sitting president incapacitated is a significant and rare action that has never been successfully executed in U.S. history. This process requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or another designated body) to formally declare that the president is unable to perform the duties of the office. Such a declaration typically arises from clear evidence of the president's inability to perform their duties, which, as of the latest available information, has not been publicly evident in President Biden's case. Additionally, political dynamics play a crucial role; initiating this process would likely require substantial bipartisan support, which seems unlikely given the current political climate. Unless there are undisclosed circumstances indicating severe incapacity, the likelihood of this amendment being invoked before September 2024 remains very low.

question.title: If Joe Biden drops out, will a reliable media outlet cover the story at least 6 hours in advance?
question.body:
Question resolves YES if a big and reliable media outlet like Associated Press News, CNN, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Reuters, or Washington Post covers the dropout with an unofficial confirmation at least 6 hours before President Joe Biden officially announces his dropout via letter, speech, etc.

Local news, conspiracy websites, or comments by individual users on Manifold will not be sufficient.

This market will be resolved as N/A if President Joe Biden does not drop out before the end of the National Democratic Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If President Joe Biden were to drop out of the race, it would be a significant political event with wide-reaching implications. Major and reliable media outlets such as CNN, The New York Times, and Reuters have extensive resources and connections that might allow them to obtain unofficial confirmations or insider information ahead of official announcements. However, these organizations also adhere to journalistic standards that emphasize accuracy and verification before reporting such significant news, which might prevent them from publishing unconfirmed reports even if they have advanced knowledge. Additionally, the coordination between the candidate's campaign and media outlets often ensures that official announcements are made simultaneously to control the narrative and avoid misinformation. Given these factors, while it's possible that a reliable media outlet might have advanced knowledge, the likelihood of them covering Biden's dropout at least 6 hours before an official announcement is relatively low.

metadata.chain_of_thought: If President Joe Biden were to drop out before the end of the National Democratic Convention, it is highly likely that major media outlets would report on the development swiftly. While an 'unofficial confirmation' suggests the information isn't directly from Biden or an official spokesperson, leaks or insider information could lead major networks to report the story before the official announcement. Historical precedents show that major political shifts are often reported by multiple outlets rapidly once credible information emerges. Therefore, the probability that at least one major media outlet would cover Biden's dropout with an unofficial confirmation at least 6 hours before an official announcement is quite high.

question.title: Iran military response before August 13th midnight Eastern Time?
question.body:
This market will resolve to "Yes" if Iran initiates a military action on Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory between July 30 and August 12, 2024, 11:59 PM ET. Otherwise, this market will resolve to "No".

For the purposes of this market, a "military action" will be considered to be any use of force executed by Iran on Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory (e.g. if a weapons depot on Israeli soil is hit by an Iranian missile, this market will resolve to "Yes") that is officially acknowledged by the Iranian government or a consensus of credible reporting. This includes, but is not limited to, airstrikes, naval attacks, or ground invasions. Cyber attacks, sanctions, or diplomatic actions will not count towards the resolution of this market.

Only responses by Iranian forces explicitly claimed by the Islamic Republic of Iran, or confirmed to have originated from Iranian territory will count toward the resolution of this market. Attacks on Israel by proxy forces (i.e. Hezbollah, Houthis, etc.) will not count toward the resolution of this market.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Iran and Israel have a history of tension and proxy conflicts, particularly involving groups like Hezbollah. However, direct military action by Iran against Israeli soil, airspace, or maritime territory would signify a major escalation with significant regional and international repercussions. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been no concrete indications that Iran is preparing to undertake such direct military actions imminently. Diplomatic efforts, economic considerations, and the potential for severe retaliation likely act as deterrents against Iran initiating a direct military strike within the specified timeframe of July 30 to August 12, 2024. While the possibility cannot be entirely ruled out given the volatility of Middle Eastern geopolitics, the likelihood remains relatively low based on available information.

question.title: Will at least 30% of Manifold respondents agree that weak AGI had been achieved before July 23, 2024?
question.body:
[image]Every month, a Manifold poll is being posted to gain the consensus view of progress towards AGI. Unlike many of the markets and questions on Manifold, these polls will simply ask "has weak AGI been achieved," rather than providing a definition of the term. The goal is that given that the term is so broad, the only way to characterize AI progress is also to allow respondents to vote based upon their own understanding.

Progress has been steady.  The previous polls are referenced here:

@/SteveSokolowski/did-openai-achieve-weak-agi-with-gp  (Answer: 15)

@/SteveSokolowski/june-2024-has-weak-agi-been-achieve  (Answer: 27)

The previous markets on this topic, which significantly understimated Manifold's belief in AI progress, were:

@/SteveSokolowski/what-percentage-of-manifold-poll-re 

@/SteveSokolowski/will-at-least-20-of-manifold-respon 

The polls will not reference any specific model, and will not define "AGI" except to state that the poll does not require that the software system be able to manipulate the physical world. The polls open on the 23rd of each month and close on the 30th.

This market will resolve to YES if the July 2024 poll results in a ratio of YES/(NO + YES) greater than or equal to 0.3. The "no opinion" respondents will be ignored. Otherwise, this question will resolve to NO.

See also:

@/SteveSokolowski/will-one-of-the-monthly-has-weak-ag

metadata.chain_of_thought: The previous Manifold polls showed that 15% and 27% of respondents agreed that weak AGI had been achieved. Considering the steady progress in AI development up to October 2023, there has been a gradual increase in the percentage of agreement. However, achieving a 30% threshold by July 2024 would require a significant shift in perception or notable advancements in AGI that convincingly demonstrate its attainment. Given the historical trends and the broad definition of "weak AGI" used in the polls, it's plausible that the percentage could reach or slightly exceed 30%, but it's not highly certain.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Based on the information provided, public opinion polls indicate that Joe Biden tends to lose to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, while generic Democrats either poll ahead or are within the margin of error compared to Trump. In Poll 1, where respondents choose between Joe Biden and Donald Trump, Trump is likely to have a significant lead. In Poll 2, where respondents choose between a generic Democrat and Donald Trump, the race is expected to be much closer or even favor the Democrat. This suggests that the difference in Trump's percentage between Poll 1 and Poll 2 is likely to be substantial. Given these dynamics, it is probable that Poll 1 will exceed Poll 2 by at least 3%.

question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 2% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6. One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error. Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 2% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)). The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.02. Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that Donald Trump will gain at least 2% among Manifold respondents when facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, we need to consider several factors:

1. **Historical Polling Data**: Public opinion polls have consistently shown Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, while other Democrats tend to poll ahead or are within the margin. This suggests that Biden may be less favorable compared to other Democratic candidates when matched directly against Trump.

2. **Representativeness of Manifold Respondents**: The key question hinges on whether Manifold respondents are representative of the general public. If Manifold respondents have similar demographics, political affiliations, and voting behaviors as the broader population, the polls are more likely to reflect the general trend. However, if Manifold has a unique user base that differs significantly from the general electorate, the results may not be generalizable.

3. **Polling Methodology**: The accuracy of the polls depends on the methodology used by Manifold. Factors such as sample size, sampling method, question wording, and timing can influence the results. If Manifold employs robust and unbiased polling methods, the results are more credible.

4. **Current Political Climate**: As of the knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the political landscape may have evolved, affecting voter preferences. Any significant events between the polling date (July 6) and the resolution date could sway public opinion.

5. **Margin of Error**: Given that public polls often have a margin of error, a 2% difference is modest. If the expected difference is within or near the margin of error, the probability of achieving at least a 2% gain for Trump becomes less certain.

Considering these factors, especially the uncertainty around the representativeness of Manifold respondents and the modest 2% threshold relative to typical polling margins, the probability that Trump will gain at least 2% among Manifold respondents is moderate.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, national polling averages have shown varying levels of support for both Donald Trump and Joe Biden. Predicting the exact lead on July 15, 2024, involves considering factors such as campaign strategies, voter turnout, current events, and potential shifts in public opinion. Given the inherent uncertainty in forecasting specific polling leads, especially within a narrow range of greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 points, the probability of Trump's lead falling precisely within this window is relatively low.

question.body:
Source: The "Domestic Opening" number listed on BoxOfficeMojo for "Trap" (2024).

question.title: [Metaculus] Will diplomatic expulsions or recalls take place between the Philippines and China before August 1, 2024?
question.body:
Will diplomatic expulsions or recalls take place between the Philippines and China before August 1, 2024?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/24034/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question resolves as Yes if before August 1, 2024, one of these four events happens, according to official statements or credible reports:

The Philippines expels at least one diplomat representing the People's Republic of China (PRC).

The Philippines recalls at least one of its diplomats stationed in the PRC.

The PRC expels at least one diplomat representing the Philippines.

The PRC recalls at least one of its diplomats stationed in the Philippines.

If there are no such reports before that date, then this resolves as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, the diplomatic relations between the Philippines and China have been marked by both cooperation and tension, primarily due to disputes in the South China Sea. While there have been periods of heightened rhetoric and minor diplomatic spats, there has not been a significant trend toward large-scale diplomatic expulsions or recalls between the two nations. Both countries have expressed interests in maintaining dialogue to manage their differences. Additionally, major diplomatic actions of the nature described typically require substantial triggers, such as severe breaches of international agreements or significant geopolitical shifts, none of which have been evident up to October 2023. Therefore, while not impossible, the likelihood of diplomatic expulsions or recalls occurring before August 1, 2024, appears relatively low.

question.title: Will Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes, before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
The most recent qualifying interview was Biden's appearance on The Howard Stern Show in April, when Biden answered questions for ~70 minutes. 

If Biden appears in another such in-person interview for at least 45 minutes, this market resolves YES. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this market resolves NO. 

This market does not include press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. It can include appearances on a podcast or late night show, or an interview edited into a show like 60 minutes. However, there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person for such appearances to count. A 50 minute video might only feature 20 minutes of video of Biden being interviewed, and so would not count.

For context, Biden's interview with Stephanopoulos in July, his appearance on Jimmy Fallon in February, and his past appearances on 60 minutes have each had less than 30 minutes of video footage of Biden being interviewed. 

You can find a list of Biden's interviews and their transcripts here.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Joe Biden, as the sitting president, has limited opportunities for extended in-person interviews outside of official engagements. While the election cycle intensifies media interactions, the trend in recent months shows that his appearances on shows and interviews have not met the 45-minute in-person criterion. Given the constraints of his schedule and the specificity of the interview requirements, it is somewhat unlikely that he will have another qualifying in-person interview before the end of July 2024. However, the approaching election may slightly increase the chances as media outlets seek more in-depth coverage.

question.title: Will the Olympic record for the men's pole vault be broken at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if at the 2024 Paris Olympics, any men's pole vault athlete clears the bar at 6.04m or higher, according to results posted by the [International Olympic Committee](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/olympic-results) or credible sources. If this does not happen, this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The current Olympic record for the men's pole vault is 6.03 meters, set by Thiago Braz da Silva in 2016. Armand Duplantis, the world record holder with a mark of 6.21 meters, is a strong contender at the 2024 Paris Olympics. Duplantis has consistently demonstrated the ability to exceed the Olympic record in various competitions leading up to the Olympics. Additionally, the level of competition among top pole vaulters remains high, increasing the likelihood that at least one athlete will surpass 6.03 meters. Considering these factors, it is probable that the Olympic record will be broken.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: I'm unable to predict future events beyond my knowledge cutoff in October 2023. Therefore, I cannot provide a probability estimate for whether President Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to declare the President incapacitated. Historically, this has been a rare and politically sensitive action, undertaken only under extreme circumstances. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there has been no significant movement or credible evidence suggesting President Biden is unable to fulfill his duties. While partisan tensions exist, initiating such a process would likely lead to substantial political backlash and could be seen as a maneuver to undermine the sitting president without legitimate cause. Additionally, there are procedural hurdles and the need for consensus among key government officials, which makes the successful invocation of Section 4 highly improbable without substantial justification.

question.title: Will a swimmer win the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: The question resolves as **Yes** if the athlete with the highest number of 2024 Olympic gold medals competes in the swimming events.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historically, swimmers have had the opportunity to compete in numerous events at the Olympics, allowing top performers to accumulate multiple gold medals. Exceptional athletes like Michael Phelps have set high benchmarks by winning a significant number of golds in a single Games. However, achieving the highest total of gold medals among all athletes remains rare and requires not only individual excellence but also dominance across many events. In recent Olympics, while swimmers continue to perform strongly, the distribution of gold medals has become more competitive across various sports, making it less likely for a single swimmer to top the overall medal count. Considering the increasing competitiveness and the broad range of events in other disciplines, the probability that a swimmer will win the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics is relatively low.

question.title: Will an athlete win the most gold medals at the 2024 Paris Olympics?
question.body: The question resolves as **Yes** if the athlete with the highest number of 2024 Olympic gold medals competes in any events.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historically, each Olympic Games sees certain athletes excel by winning multiple gold medals across different events within their sport or related disciplines. This trend is consistent due to factors like specialization, training, and the number of events available in specific sports. Given the scale and diversity of the 2024 Paris Olympics, it is highly probable that at least one athlete will outperform others by securing the highest number of gold medals. Therefore, based on historical patterns and the structure of the Games, the likelihood of an athlete winning the most gold medals is very high.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will diplomatic expulsions or recalls take place between the Philippines and China before August 1, 2024?
question.body:
Will diplomatic expulsions or recalls take place between the Philippines and China before August 1, 2024?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/24034/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question resolves as Yes if before August 1, 2024, one of these four events happens, according to official statements or credible reports:

The Philippines expels at least one diplomat representing the People's Republic of China (PRC).

The Philippines recalls at least one of its diplomats stationed in the PRC.

The PRC expels at least one diplomat representing the Philippines.

The PRC recalls at least one of its diplomats stationed in the Philippines.

If there are no such reports before that date, then this resolves as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The relationship between the Philippines and China has been complex, primarily due to disputes in the South China Sea. While there have been periodic tensions, both nations have engaged in diplomatic dialogues to manage conflicts and maintain economic ties. Diplomatic expulsions or recalls are significant actions typically reserved for severe breaches in relations or unexpected escalations. As of October 2023, there have been no major incidents indicating an imminent breakdown in diplomatic relations that would necessitate such measures. However, the geopolitical landscape in Southeast Asia is dynamic, and unforeseen events could potentially strain relations further. Given the current state of affairs and the absence of clear indicators pointing towards diplomatic expulsions or recalls, the probability of such events occurring before August 1, 2024, remains relatively low but not negligible.

question.title: Will OpenAI publicly commit to the "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle before July 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if, before July 1, 2024, both of the following are true:

- OpenAI publicly commits to the "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle via a statement from the company or a company spokesperson, such as Sam Altman. The statement may be formal (such as a press release) or informal (such as a tweet or quote in an interview). The statement from OpenAI must indicate a new level of commitment to the principle in question, relative to the time the righttowarn.ai statement was published; it cannot be a reiteration that, for example, "we already have a culture of open criticism". 
- Metaculus verifies that the company has accepted the principle to the satisfaction of at least one member of righttowarn.ai. Metaculus may reach out to select signatories or endorsers to assess their level of satisfaction with OpenAI's commitment. Statements must be at least as rigorous as "this was a good first step" for this question to resolve as **Yes**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: OpenAI has consistently emphasized transparency and responsible AI development, which suggests a willingness to engage with principles that promote open discourse and risk disclosure. However, committing publicly to a specific principle like "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" represents a formal and potentially significant policy shift. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there haven't been explicit announcements or indications from OpenAI signaling an imminent commitment of this nature. While the organization may value and encourage risk disclosure internally, making such a public commitment by July 1, 2024, would require deliberate action that hasn't been publicly indicated. Therefore, while possible, it does not appear highly likely in the given timeframe.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will the US government end its agreement directly allowing Verisign to manage th...D, before August 3, 2024?
question.body:
Will the US government end its agreement directly allowing Verisign to manage the authoritative domain name registry for the .com TLD, before August 3, 2024?

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25791/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question resolves as Yes if before August 3, 2024, the US Department of Commerce (DOC) officially terminates or sunsets its Cooperative Agreement with Verisign recognizing Verisign's management of the .com generic top-level domain (TLD). If this does not happen, this question resolves as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The management of the .com top-level domain (TLD) by Verisign has been stable and consistent for many years, with the U.S. Department of Commerce maintaining a cooperative agreement to ensure the reliability and security of the domain. There have been no public indications or official announcements suggesting that the U.S. government intends to terminate this agreement before August 3, 2024. Additionally, transitioning the management of such a critical and widely used TLD would involve significant logistical, technical, and regulatory challenges, making it unlikely to occur within the specified timeframe without prior public discourse or policy changes. Therefore, based on the current information and the lack of evidence pointing towards an impending termination, it is unlikely that the U.S. government will end its agreement with Verisign by the given date.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:



- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Chasiv Yar remains a strategically significant and contested area in the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine. Russian forces have made advances in various regions; however, they have encountered substantial resistance from Ukrainian military units and partisan activities. The control of Chasiv Yar is crucial for both logistical and tactical reasons, making it a key objective for Russian operations. Despite these objectives, several factors reduce the likelihood of Russia establishing definitive control by June 1, 2024. These factors include sustained Ukrainian defensive efforts, international support for Ukraine, potential logistical challenges for Russian forces, and the dynamic nature of the conflict which allows for shifts in territorial control. Given the complexity of the situation and the uncertainty surrounding future developments, the probability that Russia will have control of Chasiv Yar by the specified date is relatively low.

question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows any part of Ukraine under any of the following categories:

- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

The question will resolve as **No** if no part of Ukraine is assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Russia has maintained control over several regions in Ukraine, including Crimea and parts of the Donbas area. The conflict has seen fluctuating dynamics, with Ukraine making significant counteroffensives to reclaim territories. However, Russia has demonstrated resilience in holding onto key strategic locations. Given the ongoing military engagements, international support for Ukraine, and efforts towards diplomatic resolutions, it is plausible that by June 1, 2024, Russia could retain control over at least some parts of Ukraine. The likelihood of Russia expanding its control further is mitigated by Ukraine's strengthened defenses and potential shifts in international aid or sanctions impacting Russia's military capabilities.

question.title: Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate?
question.body: Resolves YES if there is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g. Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Given the timeline leading up to the 2024 Democratic National Convention (DNC) on August 12, 2024, it is highly likely that another Democratic party presidential debate will take place. Presidential debates are a standard part of the nomination process, allowing candidates to present their platforms and engage with each other before the convention. Assuming there are multiple potential Democratic nominees (e.g., Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden), the party would typically organize at least one debate to facilitate the selection of their nominee. Additionally, organizations like the Democratic National Committee often schedule debates well in advance to ensure adequate preparation time for candidates and media coverage.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context indicates that a significant number of House Democrats are actively organizing to oppose the Democratic National Committee's (DNC) plan to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination early. With 'dozens' of House Democrats involved and a drafted letter being circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman, there is substantial momentum behind this opposition. Considering there are over 100 House Democrats and approximately 50 Senate Democrats, securing 20 signatures is feasible, especially if multiple letters are being coordinated. Additionally, internal party disagreements suggest that enough members may feel compelled to publicly dissent to showcase varying viewpoints within the party. While the existence of the letter hasn't been officially confirmed by all parties involved, the level of organization and the number of individuals reportedly supporting the effort increase the likelihood of reaching the 20-signature threshold.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will the US government end its agreement directly allowing Verisign to manage th...D, before August 3, 2024?
question.body:
Will the US government end its agreement directly allowing Verisign to manage the authoritative domain name registry for the .com TLD, before August 3, 2024?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25791/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question resolves as Yes if before August 3, 2024, the US Department of Commerce (DOC) officially terminates or sunsets its Cooperative Agreement with Verisign recognizing Verisign's management of the .com generic top-level domain (TLD). If this does not happen, this question resolves as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been no significant indications or policy shifts suggesting that the US government intends to terminate its agreement with Verisign for managing the .com top-level domain (TLD) before August 3, 2024. The .com TLD is a critical component of the global internet infrastructure, and Verisign has managed it effectively for decades under a stable contractual relationship with the US Department of Commerce. Any decision to end this agreement would require substantial justification, given the potential disruptions to the domain name system, economic implications, and the need for a seamless transition to another registry operator. Additionally, there have been no major controversies or issues with Verisign's management that would prompt such a termination in the near term. Therefore, it is unlikely that the US government will end its agreement with Verisign for the .com TLD before the specified date.

question.title: Will "Twisters" (2024) have a Rotten Tomatoes critics score of at least 75%? ("Certified Fresh")
question.body:
"Twisters" (2024) Rotten Tomatoes page

This resolves YES if the Tomatometer score is 75% or higher, one week after release (July 26th). 

Details 

I will use whatever precision is listed by Rotten Tomatoes (typically an integer percentage, no decimal).

For example, the original "Twister" (1996) currently has a Tomatometer of 63%. This is the equivalent score I will use.

"Certified Fresh" is just used for illustrative purposes (AFAIK, it requires >=75% Tomatometer, but there might be other restrictions—the market resolves solely based on the displayed score).

"Twisters" (2024) is a standalone sequel to the 1996 original, directed by Lee Isaac Chung ("Minari"), starring Glen Powell ("Top Gun: Maverick") and Daisy Edgar Jones ("Normal People").

metadata.chain_of_thought: The original "Twister" (1996) received a Tomatometer score of 63%, indicating a mixed critical reception. The upcoming "Twisters" (2024) is directed by Lee Isaac Chung, renowned for the critically acclaimed "Minari," which suggests a strong directorial vision and potential for high-quality storytelling. The cast includes Glen Powell, known for his role in "Top Gun: Maverick," and Daisy Edgar Jones from "Normal People," both of whom have been part of well-received projects. Given the standalone nature of the sequel, there is an opportunity to improve upon the original's shortcomings. Additionally, advancements in filmmaking technology and storytelling techniques over the years may contribute to a more polished and engaging film. Considering these factors—the reputable director, talented cast, potential for narrative improvement, and positive industry trends—the probability that "Twisters" (2024) will achieve a Rotten Tomatoes critics score of at least 75% appears favorable.

question.title: Will Israel carry out a deadly attack within Iran before May 1, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves **Yes** if, following the date of this question's publication and before May 1, 2024, credible reports indicate that an attack attributed to Israel and occurring within Iran's borders has led to the death of at least five individuals.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, Israel and Iran have maintained a tense and adversarial relationship, characterized by mutual distrust and periodic military engagements. Iran has been involved in supporting proxy groups across the Middle East, which Israel views as a significant security threat. Historically, both nations have engaged in covert operations and have a vested interest in preventing the other's regional influence. However, direct large-scale attacks are relatively rare due to the potential for significant retaliation and escalation. Diplomatic efforts, international pressure, and strategic considerations often play roles in deterring such actions. Given the lack of specific intelligence or indicators suggesting an imminent attack within the timeframe specified (between April 13, 2024, and May 1, 2024), and considering the potential consequences of such an action for both nations and the broader region, it seems unlikely that Israel would carry out a deadly attack within Iran in the immediate future.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Invoking the 25th Amendment Section 4 requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to declare that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of the office. As of October 2023, there has been no credible indication or significant political movement within the administration or the Cabinet to support such a declaration against President Biden. Furthermore, such an action would represent a highly unprecedented and politically charged move, with likely significant resistance within the President’s own party. Given the lack of evidence or credible signs that the Vice President and Cabinet are considering this action, the probability that President Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August is extremely low.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will the domestic box office opening of "Deadpool & Wolverine" be higher than th..."The Wolverine" combined?
question.body:
Will the domestic box office opening of "Deadpool & Wolverine" be higher than that of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" combined?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25850/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question resolves as Yes if the domestic box office opening for the Deadpool & Wolverine reported by Boxofficemojo on the movie's page is higher than $185,548,391 which is the sum of the box openings for Deadpool (2016) and The Wolverine (2013): $132,434,639 + $53,113,752.

1. **Franchise Popularity**: Both Deadpool and Wolverine are highly popular characters with dedicated fan bases. A crossover could generate significant interest due to the unique combination of their storylines and personalities.

2. **Marketing and Hype**: Effective marketing campaigns can significantly boost opening weekend numbers. If the studio invests heavily in promoting the crossover, it could attract a larger audience.

3. **Release Timing**: The timing of the movie release plays a crucial role. Releasing during peak movie-going seasons or avoiding competition with other major blockbusters can enhance box office performance.

4. **Critical Reception and Word of Mouth**: Positive reviews and strong word-of-mouth recommendations can drive more viewers to theaters, potentially increasing the opening weekend revenue.

5. **Comparable Performances**: Looking at other successful Marvel crossovers and ensemble films, there's precedent for higher box office openings when multiple beloved characters are involved.

Considering these factors, if 'Deadpool & Wolverine' is executed well in terms of production quality, marketing, and timing, it's plausible that the movie could surpass the combined openings of its predecessors.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Invoking Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to declare President Biden incapacitated requires the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to formally assess and agree that the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there have been no credible indications or movements within the administration or among Vice President and Cabinet members to support such a measure. Additionally, invoking the 25th Amendment is a significant and rare step, typically reserved for clear and manifest incapacitation, which does not appear to be the case with President Biden. Therefore, the likelihood of the 25th Amendment being invoked against President Biden before August 2024 is exceedingly low.

question.title: Will Russian athletes be barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Russian athletes are barred from competing at the 2024 Olympics under either (i) the Russian flag, (ii) The Russian Olympic Committee's flag, or (iii) any other independent or neutral flag. This will resolve based on the official list of countries and athletes present at the [2024 Olympics](https://olympics.com/en/olympic-games/paris-2024) or based on credible media reports, indicating that the 2024 Olympics are underway or have concluded without Russian participation. For the question to resolve as **Yes**, no more than 34 Russians can be competing at the 2024 Olympics. 34 was chosen as 10% of [Russian athletes that participated in the 2020 Olympics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Olympic_Committee_athletes_at_the_2020_Summer_Olympics) to allow for a few individual or sport specific exceptions.

If more than 34 Russian athletes compete at the 2024 Olympics, this question will resolve as **No**.

If the 2024 Olympics are cancelled or postponed to 2025 or afterwards, this question resolves as ambiguously.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of October 2023, Russian athletes have been participating in international competitions under the designation "Authorized Neutral Athletes" due to ongoing sanctions related to doping violations. The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has maintained a stance that allows Russian athletes to compete if they meet specific criteria and do not represent Russia under its national flag. Historical precedents from the 2018 PyeongChang and 2020 Tokyo Olympics show that a limited number of Russian athletes were permitted to compete under neutral flags. Given the geopolitical tensions and the IOC's careful approach to maintaining fair play standards, it's plausible that a similar policy will be applied to the 2024 Paris Olympics. However, the exact number of Russian athletes allowed can vary based on ongoing compliance with anti-doping regulations and any new geopolitical developments. Considering these factors, it is moderately likely that the number of Russian athletes competing under neutral or independent flags will remain at or below the 34-athlete threshold defined for the resolution of this question as "Yes."

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

question.title: Will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question resolves as **No** if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in these eight team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics: 

- association football 
- 3×3 basketball
- 5×5 basketball
- field hockey
- handball 
- rugby sevens
- volleyball
- water polo.

Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **Yes**.

The question can resolve as soon as it becomes clear one of these conditions will happen (e.g. neither team playing the final of the last event has won any of the others).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The United States has historically shown strong performances across multiple women's team sports, including 5×5 basketball, volleyball, and water polo. Their investment in athletics, depth of talent, and coaching expertise provide them with a competitive advantage in these events. Additionally, countries like the Netherlands and Australia also exhibit strength in multiple team sports, which could contribute to a single nation securing more than one gold medal. Considering the overlapping areas of dominance and the depth of competition, it is likely that at least one nation will excel in multiple women's team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Predicting the exact price of silver on a specific future date involves considerable uncertainty due to the myriad factors that influence metal prices. As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, silver prices have been influenced by factors such as inflation rates, interest rates, geopolitical tensions, industrial demand, and investment trends.

1. **Economic Indicators**: If inflation remains high, investors often turn to precious metals like silver as a hedge, potentially driving prices up. Conversely, if inflation cools and interest rates rise, it might strengthen the US dollar, making silver more expensive in other currencies and possibly reducing demand.

2. **Industrial Demand**: Silver has significant industrial applications, including in electronics and renewable energy technologies. Growth in these sectors can increase demand for silver, supporting higher prices.

3. **Investment Demand**: Silver is also an investment asset. Increased investment demand, especially during economic uncertainty, can push prices upwards. Funds flow into silver ETFs and physical silver can influence the price positively.

4. **Geopolitical Factors**: Political instability or conflicts can lead to increased demand for safe-haven assets like silver, potentially boosting its price.

5. **Supply Considerations**: Mining output and stockpiles also play a role. Any disruptions in silver mining or reductions in supply can lead to price increases.

6. **Market Sentiment and Speculation**: Traders' perceptions and speculative activities can cause short-term price volatility, impacting the price at a specific point in time.

Given these factors, while there is potential for silver to exceed $30.50 USD per ounce by August 9th, 2024, it is subject to significant uncertainties. Historical data shows that silver prices have been volatile, and reaching this specific price point would depend on how the aforementioned factors play out over the next year.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of my knowledge cutoff in October 2023, there has been ongoing tension between Israel and Iran, particularly concerning Iran's nuclear program and its support for proxy groups in the region. question.title: Will the maximum weekly rate of hospitalizations per 100,000 in the US occur within four weeks of the combined peak for each of COVID, influenza, and RSV in the 2023-24 season?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the maximum weekly rate of hospitalizations per 100,000 for each of COVID, influenza, and RSV that occurs in the 2023-24 season is less than or equal to four weeks (28 days) from the date of the maximum rate for all three combined, according to the CDC's [RESP-NET](https://www.cdc.gov/surveillance/resp-net/dashboard.html). The four weeks will be based on the week end dates. The CDC uses "epidemiological weeks" which begin on Sunday and end on Saturday. The rate used will be that for all ages, races, and sexes. See the fine print for the correct filters. For the purposes of this question, the 2023-2024 season will be considered to begin with the week ending on October 7, 2023, and end on the week ending June 1, 2024.

To allow for data revisions and reporting delays the question will resolve according to data shown after the reporting delay period, when the relevant figures for the current season is not shown as a dashed line, typically 4 weeks after the week end date.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historical patterns of respiratory illnesses like COVID-19, influenza, and RSV often show overlapping and closely timed peaks in hospitalization rates, typically influenced by factors such as virus transmissibility, public health interventions, and population immunity levels. In past seasons, the peaks for these viruses have often occurred within a few weeks of each other, especially during the peak respiratory virus season in winter months. For the 2023-24 season, assuming no significant changes in these influencing factors—such as the emergence of new variants, changes in public health policies, or substantial shifts in population immunity—it is reasonable to expect that the maximum weekly hospitalization rates for each of these viruses would align closely, potentially within a four-week window. However, variability in virus behavior and external factors could lead to deviations from this pattern. Taking these considerations into account, there is a relatively high likelihood that the maximum hospitalization rates will occur within four weeks of the combined peak.

The four weeks will be based on the week end dates. The CDC uses "epidemiological weeks" which begin on Sunday and end on Saturday. The rate used will be that for all ages, races, and sexes. See the fine print for the correct filters. For the purposes of this question, the 2023-2024 season will be considered to begin with the week ending on October 7, 2023, and end on the week ending June 1, 2024.

To allow for data revisions and reporting delays the question will resolve according to data shown after the reporting delay period, when the relevant figures for the current season is not shown as a dashed line, typically 4 weeks after the week end date.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: Historically, the peaks of COVID-19, influenza, and RSV hospitalizations in the U.S. have tended to occur within a relatively close timeframe during the respiratory virus season. In recent seasons, especially with the overlapping circulation patterns influenced by public health measures and virus characteristics, these peaks have often been aligned within a few weeks of each other. For the 2023-24 season, considering factors such as continued vaccination efforts, potential changes in virus transmissibility, and public health interventions, it is reasonable to expect that the maximum weekly hospitalization rates for COVID-19, influenza, and RSV will occur within a four-week window of the combined peak. Additionally, advancements in surveillance and data reporting may contribute to more synchronized peak detection.

For COVID-19, the peak hospitalization period has also tended to align with these respiratory seasons, especially as mitigation measures are relaxed and population immunity stabilizes. Given the current trends in the 2023-24 season up to October 2023, and assuming no significant changes in virus behavior or public health policies, it is plausible that the maximum weekly rate of COVID-19 hospitalizations will occur within four weeks of the combined peak for COVID, influenza, and RSV. question.title: Will Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes, before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
The most recent qualifying interview was Biden's appearance on The Howard Stern Show in April, when Biden answered questions for ~70 minutes. 

If Biden appears in another such in-person interview for at least 45 minutes, this market resolves YES. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this market resolves NO. 

This market does not include press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. It can include appearances on a podcast or late night show, or an interview edited into a show like 60 minutes. However, there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person for such appearances to count. A 50 minute video might only feature 20 minutes of video of Biden being interviewed, and so would not count.

For context, Biden's interview with Stephanopoulos in July, his appearance on Jimmy Fallon in February, and his past appearances on 60 minutes have each had less than 30 minutes of video footage of Biden being interviewed. 

You can find a list of Biden's interviews and their transcripts here.

This trend suggests a preference for shorter interview formats in recent months. Considering the timeframe before the end of July 2024, there may be limited opportunities for such extensive interviews due to his involvement in the 2024 presidential campaign, which often constrains the availability for long-form media engagements. Additionally, securing a new in-person interview of 45+ minutes would require coordinating with media outlets willing to allocate sufficient time, which appears less likely given the recent pattern. Therefore, the probability of Joe Biden having another in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes before the end of July 2024 is relatively low.
